Title:
Ecological speciation in the cone-inhabiting Auriscalpium
vulgare complex
Keywords:
species diversity, ecological speciation, mating gene,
cophylogenetic analysis, substrate specificities or preferences,
geographic distributions.
Abstract:
Basidiomes of Auriscalpium vulgare complex on conifer
cones are widely distributed across the Northern Hemisphere and easily
recognized because of their unique macro-morphology. However, their
phylogenetic diversity patterns among different geographic populations
and different substrates are completely unknown. In this study, the
species of the A. vulgare complex that occurs on old cones of pine trees
from many parts of China were studied phylogenetically, morphologically
and ecologically. Our phylogenetic analyses based on nucleotide
sequences the internal transcribed spacers 1 and 2 with the 5.8S nrDNA
(ITS), the large subunit of nuclear ribosomal RNA (nrLSU), the
translation elongation factor 1-α (TEF1-α) gene, and the region between
the conserved domain 6 and 7 of the gene for the second largest subunit
of RNA polymerase II (RPB2), and the partial sequence of the homeodomain
(HD) of the mating gene indicated that three phylogenetic species can be
recognized, which correspond well with morphological and ecological
evidence. Therefore, three species, with two new to science, are
documented here, namely the well-known A. vulgare, and the newly
described species A. orientale and A. microsporum. Although A. vulgare
is restricted in the northeastern parts of China and the new species are
mainly in the south, they all have distinct substrate specificities or
preferences. Our cophylogenetic analyses indicated that both
cospeciation, and duplication and host switch contributed to the
speciation of A. vulgare complex. In conclusion, ecological adaptations
to different substrates have driven the formation of the species in the
A. vulgare complex.
